title: Performance of High Entropy Alloys Under Severe Environments via In-situ Transmission Electron Microscopy-Irradiation Experiments
content: Beyond the current coarse-grain W approach [1], multiple strategies are being pursued in the quest for new materials that can withstand severe irradiation, thermal, and mechanical extremes for advanced fusion applications [2]. In the last two decades, a novel set of alloys known as high-entropy alloys (HEAs) with nearly equi-atomic compositions of principal constituent elements have been developed [3, 4]. HEAs represent a radical departure from traditional alloy design, which involves a single principal alloying element with small additions (<20 at%) of alloying elements chosen to achieve specific properties. Refractory HEAs ( have been recently developed for high-temperature applications [5] and possess high melting temperatures (above 2873 K) and superior high-temperature mechanical properties as compared to Ni-based superalloys or pure tungsten [6, 7]. For fusion applications, where W is the main choice as a plasma facing component, HEAs can offer some advantages. However, high throughput characterization of the performance of these materials is critical to down-select elements and compositions relevant to the application.
